There's a surge of women running for office and within that we're also seeing a high number of black women running for federal office forty one black women are running for the house thirty five of whom are Democrats that's in the ... that's
Most in recent years according to the center for American women and politics at Rutgers University
These women are trying to close a big representation gap but that heightened visibility comes with a different set of challenges
In late August ... more is the only woman in Vermont legislature dropped out of her reelection race because of race it's online threats and harassment black women also face extra hurdles when campaigning like gathering funding and national endorsements
Kimberly peeler Allen is here to talk about these issues and she's the co founder of higher hype for America
In organization working to elect black women for public office Kimberly thanks for joining us on the take away is a pleasure to be here what an interesting topic to says I'm let's talk a little bit about motivation right what I mean we were hearing this is a year if the woman and everybody wants to run for office but
There's one is particularly driving woman of color more specifically black women to run for office
Smith black women also face extra hurdles when campaigning like gathering funding and national endorsements
Kimberly peeler Allen is here to talk about these issues and she's the co founder of higher hype for America
In organization working to elect black women for public office Emily thanks for joining us on the take away it is a pleasure to be here what an interesting topic this is um let's talk a little bit about motivation right what I mean we were hearing was the year if the woman and everybody wants to run for office but
There's one is particularly driving women of color more specifically black women to run for office well I think it is um
You know this confluence of events that we are that we find ourselves in a black woman had been running and doing the work behind the scenes for generations and you're thinking back to like Fannie Lou Hamer and Barbara Jordan you know women had been a black woman had been in the trenches
And now there is this new sense of urgency we're seeing the attempts and in many cases the actual reality of the roll back to the last fifty years of progress
And we're seeing that you know black women are saying I Can't let this happen to my community so I'm going to step up and run and it is um that combined with
Uh the electorate realizing that you know over eighty percent of our elected officials across the country are white and male
And that is you know by no means represents the diversity in this nation and the electorate is saying you know we need to have some different voices around the table
And these black women are speaking to my issues are regardless of you know the fact that they're black or they can appeal to everybody and it has really been a great um catalyst for all of these women to run such strong primaries and you know we're really looking forward
To some great pickups on November sex so let's talk a little bit about that because there are some challenges specifically and we know politics is is like any other industry right there are challenges as we mentioned to funding and and getting support here

And I'm Wondering if you think black women candidates are thought of by the Democratic party as less viable because of who they are because they can't raise the money because they won't give them the

Born out of the notion that we needed a space for black women a political home for black women and go into a car and I we knew from our experience that the the you know factors that make a black woman a viable candidate or not necessarily the same as our white counterparts
And we know that by mobilizing our networks because that is what we do just you know to make life happen for so many of us
And the volunteer effort and the word of mouth and then also be bringing our authentic selves or to the campaign trail has really been
A a great factor in the successes so we've always looked at Kennedy to a walk in the spirit of Shirley Chisholm on bought and on Boston we look at what kind of a volunteer structure they have we look at
A you know do they have enough money to reach their constituents we don't need you know the hundreds of millions of dollars that so many of
These races costs but do you have the baseline of what it's going to take for you to reach your target voters and do you have a solid campaign plan
And you know are you in line with issues that we believe will make sure that black women in their communities and their families thrive

Are there specific barriers to fund raising that black women candidates face in particular

But I think it is also a thinking through it's not just the the large checks but
Uh being able to mobilize our networks for those you know monthly five dollar contributions that add up over time
